qas.question: Why did the Grand Orient de France conclude that Freemasonry shouldn't require religious belief?
What was removed from the Freemasonry constitution?

answers.text: existence of God and the immortality of the soul

qas.question: Who withdrew recognition from the Grand Orient de France?
What was a possible condition that made the United Grand Lodge of England withdraw it's recognition of the Grand Orient de France?

answers.text: political tension between France and Britain

qas.question: How was the belief of the existance of God and the immortal soul replaced in the constitution?

answers.text: Its principles are absolute liberty of conscience and human solidarity

qas.question: What year was it ruled that Freemasonry was not a religion?
What Grand Lodge had a withdrawal of recognition by the United Grand Lodge of England?
What was a motivation of the Grand Lodge of England's objection?

answers.text: political tension between France and Britain

qas.question: Who disputed the Lausanne Congress of Supreme Councils?
Why did the Grand Orient de France conclude that Freemasonry should require religious belief?

plausible_answers.text: the existence of God and the immortality of the soul

qas.question: What was added to the Freemasonry constitution?

plausible_answers.text: the United Grand Lodge of England

qas.question: Who maintained permanent recognition with the Grand Orient de France?

plausible_answers.text: Its principles are absolute liberty of conscience and human solidarity

qas.question: How was the belief of the existence of God and the immortal soul explained in the constitution?
What year was it ruled that Freemasonry was a religion?

context: A dispute during the Lausanne Congress of Supreme Councils of <a5_0><b13_0>1875<b13_0/><a5_0/> prompted the <a8_0>Grand Orient de France<a8_0/> to commission a report by a Protestant pastor which concluded that, as <a0_0><b9_0>Freemasonry was not a religion<b9_0/><a0_0/>, it should not require a religious belief. The new constitutions read, "<a4_0><b12_0>Its principles are absolute liberty of conscience and human solidarity<b12_0/><a4_0/>", <b10_0>the <a1_0>existence of God and the immortality of the soul<b10_0/><a1_0/> being struck out. It is possible that the immediate objections of <b11_0>the United Grand Lodge of England<b11_0/> were at least partly motivated by the <a3_0><a7_0>political tension between France and Britain<a7_0/><a3_0/> at the time. The result was the withdrawal of recognition of the <a6_0>Grand Orient of France<a6_0/> by the <a2_0>United Grand Lodge of England<a2_0/>, a situation that continues today.
